title: 109_s1539
content: The "Adoption Equality Act of 2005" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The Adoption and Safe Families Act of 1997 prioritizes a child's health and safety, aiming to provide each child with a permanent home. This Act also offers incentives for adoptions, resulting in the placement of nearly 53,000 children from State care in fiscal year 2002. The Adoption Promotion Act of 2003 further emphasized moving older children into permanent homes. In 2003, despite increased adoptions, over 118,000 foster children still await adoption, many with special needs requiring federal support for healing from past abuse and neglect. SEC. 3. PROMOTION OF ADOPTION OF CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL NEEDS. The amendment to Section 473(a) of the Social Security Act pertains to the requirements for a child to qualify under certain circumstances related to termination of parental rights and placement in care of a public or licensed private agency. The State has determined that continuation in the home would be contrary to the safety or welfare of the child, who meets all medical or disability requirements for supplemental security income benefits, or was residing in a foster family home or child care institution with the child's minor parent. Additionally, the child has been determined by the State to be a child with special needs, which will be considered in the adoption process. "A child with special needs, not a US citizen or resident, meeting adoption assistance requirements, shall be treated as meeting the requirements for payments. Eligible for adoption assistance payments under this." "A child meeting adoption assistance requirements due to prior adoption dissolution or parental rights termination shall be treated as meeting payment eligibility." "A child meeting adoption assistance requirements due to prior adoption dissolution or parental rights termination shall be treated as meeting payment eligibility. No payment may be made to parents for a child with special needs who is not a citizen or resident of the United States and was adopted outside of the United States." Section 473(a) of the Social Security Act requires the use of state savings for children adopted outside the United States or brought into the country for adoption purposes. This provision does not prohibit payments for children placed in foster care after a failed adoption. Section 473(a) of the Social Security Act mandates that states must allocate savings from adoption-related expenditures towards providing services to children or families, as per the Adoption Equality Act of 2005. The Social Security Act requires states to allocate adoption-related savings for services to children or families, including post-adoption services. Section 473(c) defines a child with special needs as one who cannot be returned home or meets medical/disability criteria for title XVI eligibility. The Social Security Act requires states to allocate adoption-related savings for services to children or families, including post-adoption services. A child with special needs is defined as one who cannot be returned home or meets medical/disability criteria for title XVI eligibility, based on specific factors or conditions determined by the State. The Social Security Act mandates states to use adoption-related savings for services to children or families, including post-adoption services. A child with special needs is one who cannot be placed with adoptive parents without adoption and medical assistance, except in cases where it is against the child's best interests due to emotional ties with prospective adoptive parents. The amendments made by this section regarding adoption assistance for children with special needs will take effect on October 1, 2005.
